description: From Middle English mercy, merci, from Anglo-Norman merci (compare continental Old French merci, mercit), from Latin mercēs (“wages, fee, price”), from merx (“wares, merchandise”). Displaced native Old English mildheortnes. Cognate with French merci.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Relenting; forbearance to cause or allow harm to another.
examples: She took mercy on him and quit embarrassing him.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) Forgiveness or compassion, especially toward those less fortunate.
examples: Have mercy on the poor and assist them if you can.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A tendency toward forgiveness, pity, or compassion.
examples: Mercy is one of his many virtues.
Psalms 40:11 Do not withhold Your tender mercies from me, O Lord

entries.meaning: (countable) A blessing; something to be thankful for.
examples: It was a mercy that we were not inside when the roof collapsed

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A children's game in which two players stand opposite with hands grasped and twist each other's arms until one gives in.

verbs.description: mercy (third-person singular simple present mercies, present participle mercying, simple past and past participle mercied)

entries.meaning: To show mercy; to pardon or treat leniently because of mercy
